32.text:
We're shooting, of course we are shooting,
but first we are fishing.

44.text:
We have invited a few friends to join us,
swapping guns for rods on a sea water fishing

56.text:
trip. We are heading out from Eastbourne's
Sovereign Harbour with Deep Blue Charters.

62.text:
We've chosen this particular vessel with Steve
the skipper, because this is the boat is responsible

66.text:
for landing a record breaking cod: the largest
ever specimen caught by a rod in the English

73.text:
Channel. Novice Chris Procter battled for
half an hour to reel in the 43lb 9oz fishzilla.

82.text:
We are of course expecting great things but,
just in case, Steve suggests we bring along

87.text:
some experience as well as beauty. Father
and son team Adrian and Tim Colliver are on

94.text:
call to ensure a decent haul and to tell us
all about their rotten bottoms.

99.text:
What I am doing here is I'm just setting up
the rig for what we call gilling, so we drift

105.text:
over the wreck, we lie the tackle down and
this is a shed, and then we retrieve it by

112.text:
winding in and hopefully the fish will come
up and grab it.

115.text:
It's got a lot of weight on it. You want it
to go deep.

119.text: So it's got weights inside it?

122.text:
It has indeed, and that trace is probably
4 or 5 feet and when it is connected to a

126.text:
boom and a weight, the weight is attached
to the boom, has a rotten bottom in case it

135.text:
Yes, so if it catches in the wreck the line
will break and hopefully we will retrieve

141.text:
Gilling is what I said, it's lowering the
lure to the seabed over the wreck and retrieving

146.text:
it and hopefully the fish, bass, cod, pollock
will take the lure, put a bend in the rod

158.text:
The lure is all important, jelly worms and
rhubarb custard are apparently irresistible

165.text: The pollock particularly like jelly worms.

168.text:
Yes, so it has to be something which has a
bit of movement.

174.text:
It's the action. That's a rhubarb and custard
and they are very good. They work extremely

180.text: well, catch a lot of fish these ones.

184.text:
The weather is fantastic which is a good job
as we have got more than an hour to get to

189.text:
the ship wrecks of plenty. There has been
plenty of talk about sea sickness too. Sporting

195.text:
Shooter editor Dom Holtam vowed never to go
sea fishing again after a stag-do up north

201.text:
where he was told that 'beer and water don't
mix, boy'. Sporting Rifle's Tim Pilbeam recommends

208.text:
plenty of eating throughout the day. As for
my old friend Keith Curtis, it is a bit of

214.text:
a busman's holiday as he runs Brick Farm Lakes,
a trout farm fishery in East Sussex. Incredibly,

221.text: however, Keith has never ever caught a fish.

227.text:
With nausea at bay, we are out at sea when
we reach our first wreck of the day. The white

233.text:
Loch-Ness-monster-style arc on the left of
the hump is our fish. We are told to drop

239.text:
our line until we hit the bottom and then
reel in 20 turns. We hope our sidewinder lures

245.text:
will prove a tempting snack for cod and pollock.
Tim is the first to get a nibble, rhubarb

252.text:
and custard proving to be too tempting for
this little pollock. Next in is Dom with another

258.text:
pollock. As much as we appreciate Adrian and
Tim's efforts, no one else is getting a chance

263.text:
with rhubarb and custard which keeps delivering
the fish for Colliver junior. Just the size

269.text:
cod that dad, Adrian, likes to eat and kiss.
Now here's a moment to share, fish farmer

277.text:
Keith catches his first ever fish, in his
mid forties, a lovely looking cod. He is dedicating

287.text:
There is no stopping the man, he's struck
again, but it is a pouting described by the

291.text:
more experienced anglers on board as the turkey
twizzler of the ocean, so he puts it back

299.text:
The weather might be bright, but the wind
and the tide are coming from different directions.

304.text:
This part of the film does not contain flash
photography, but a wobbly horizon as we chat

310.text:
with skipper, ex British team clay shot, Steve
Bradshaw.

314.text: You're known to the world as a shooter originally.

317.text:
And you're in the middle of the sea. How does
that work?

320.text:
I'm not sure really how it's happened. I've
always been involved with fishing and shooting,

324.text:
so mainly from small boats myself and fishing
on weekends and progressed from there really.

330.text: And this boat, you are out most of the year?

339.text:
And a cash commitment as well, it's an expensive
piece of kit isn't it?

343.text:
You're looking, most charter boats, new charter
boats now, a 40 foot decent boat, you're looking

348.text:
at in excess of GBP150,000. So quite a big
investment for a start, yes.

353.text:
And you are really going for it as one of
the top boats in the country?

357.text: We're out an awfully long way?

359.text: We're a long way from home, yes.

361.text: Yes, we are closer to France.

363.text:
We are closer to France at the moment are
we? Most boats don't go this far off shore?

371.text:
Some of the top boats will, yes. I wouldn't
say most of the top boats, but a lot of the

376.text:
top boats will certainly put the mileage in
to get customers fish.

380.text:
And what has this yielded, what sort of records
have you pulled out?

384.text:
I currently hold one of the largest UK cod
in the English Channel from this year, being

391.text: Was that the one that was in all the papers?

394.text:
Yes, I've had a good season, a good start
to the season with lots of double figures

399.text:
well into 30lb, lots of fish around 30. One
previous to that 36. A lot of good fish.

408.text:
And this is about getting people into fish
for sure, into fishing.

412.text:
Yes, sure, yes definitely. It's one of the
sports where you never know what is going

416.text:
to happen. With shooting pretty much, in a
field of shooters, your top ten shooters will

422.text:
always come out on top all the time, but with
fishing you never know what's going to happen.

428.text:
While we have been chatting, Dom has been
catching. He's got a cod so he's stopped thinking

434.text:
On a day like this, when it's sunny and warm
and not too rough, but I've had some bad experiences,

I won't lie to you David, it can be pretty
unpleasant and I'm pretty fearful I may vomit

447.text: before the end of the day.

449.text:
The other members of the party are fairing
better even though not all are having the

455.text:
I'm just hoping for that lure to come up,

464.text:
Well, I think actually seeing the fish come

looking at them and the whole concept of dangling

grabbing is just brilliant. It really is good,
so I just rather hope I can catch a fish in

481.text:
You own a trout fishery Keith and today you
have just caught your first fish.

490.text: I've never had time to go fishing before.

493.text:
Is it a very high powered, high intensity
job running a fishery?

499.text:
It's a busy time, it's a busy place to run.
I have to give all my attention to the fishery.

507.text:
Tim is now on fire, three fish in quick succession,
and Dad is starting to feel the pressure.

514.text:
Caught by my boy, again, again. Adrian is
Jonah.

522.text: Six or seven now Dad, isn't it?

We move to another couple of wrecks and get

gannet as Adrian guts his or should I say

538.text:
base and have one last spot to try. Adrian
is drinking at the Last Chance Saloon, but

544.text: manages to save face with a codling.

548.text:
Got one after many hours of blanking. There
you go, there's my tea for tonight.

561.text:
Once we are back inside outer harbour a match
debrief with our experts.

568.text: So we had a pretty good day.

570.text: Yes, not bad, half a dozen or so.

574.text: You couldn't go wrong, every time.

575.text:
Yes, just one of those things trying to ring
the changes a little bit with the lures, mixture

581.text:
of I think a couple of pollock, rest were
cod I think, bit of a mixture.

590.text:
Yes, started off with the rhubarb and custard,
had the first three or so on that.

596.text:
He's not bitter you know. You can tell he's
not bitter at all.

601.text:
The fish came quite early, wrecks, how many
wrecks, fished three wrecks today?

606.text:
First wreck produced the majority of the fish
quite early on. I don't know if they got spooked

611.text:
a little bit after we had been on there for
a while. Tried a couple of other wrecks and

616.text: you pulled one out of the bag very last.

618.text:
Yes, last knockings, at least I didn't blank
completely.

620.text: Aren't you just glad you taught him so well?

623.text:
Yes, I think so. It speaks for itself doesn't
it.

627.text:
Like that, there's a contour on the head here,
just keep the knife in.

633.text:
As we will all be having a fish supper tonight,
Steve gives us a quick demo of fish filleting,

638.text: so we don't make a hash of it later.

641.text:
It really has been a great day, fish were
caught and no one was ill. Dom is probably

647.text:
more relieved than most that we are back at
the jetty.

651.text:
I did enjoy myself, I did feel queasy for
a lot of the trip, but it is great fun and

659.text:
I do love fishing. For a group of mates to
pay GBP40, GBP50 a head and have a day out

664.text:
together catching fish and being able to take
home the catch at the end of the day for a

668.text:
barbecue or whatever, I think it's a great
way for a day out doing something different.

673.text:
There are fishing opportunities all around
the UK, different species, different areas,

678.text:
so yes it's a good thing to do, support your
local fishermen.

684.text:
Well while we heave to and whistle for a wind,
let's head back to that landlubber David on

701.text:
Police are warning of the dangers of brandishing

705.text:

deployed in Inverness after a 15 year old

710.text:
boy was seen brandishing a firearm in public.
The teenager caused fear and alarm to passers

715.text:
by when he brandished the BB gun. The police
said: "People who carry such items are not

720.text:
thinking about the possible consequences of

729.text:
Pete Wilson is now favourite to win gold in
Double Trap in London 2012 after setting a

734.text:
new world record score as he won the men's
double trap gold at the Shotgun World Cup

739.text:
in Arizona. The 25 year-old from Dorset hit
198 of 200 targets on his way to victory,

746.text: beating the record of 196 set in 2009.

752.text:
The summer's game fair season is getting underway.

Fair at Kelmarsh Hall in Northamptonshire.
Among an international line-up of attractions

fishing village. The two-day fair is on the

You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories, fishing for facts.

1164.text:
Staying with shotguns and we're after bouncing

1170.text:
When Roy is not hurling birds of prey at rabbits,

1175.text:
control day today as the rabbits on this farm
are causing a right old mess of the hedgerow.

We've got a nice set of earths here running

and we're very near to the fences, rather

Elmer-Fudd-style today with a shotgun. So

Ferrets are key today, but they can be frustrating,

breaks cover. The boys are not missing many
and Roy thinks they have the perfect strategy

considering the thickness of the cover above

That's the other good thing about bolting

hearing us so they are popping out and just

1374.text: all country and western on us - yee hah.

1388.text:
This is a Browning BL .22 underlever, very

1398.text:
.22 calibre. It has got a 15-shot magazine
and if you are using .22 long rifle it will

1406.text:

capacity of the magazine. Traditionally it

it's quite a high-tech bit of kit for a rifle

once we've got it set up accurate enough for

Ambidextrous so ideal for cack-handed shooters

1462.text:
like myself. Quite short in the stock so probably

We've got this set up and we've just zeroed

off sticks rather than shooting off a bipod

action, but good enough to go and have a crack

So before we head off and try and pop a few

So that was the end to a not-entirely-successful
